I love Michael Jordan. He is undoubtedly the most electrifying player in NBA history. He is also the most feared and revered player of all time. But LeBron James is a better player. James focused more on team play and made the players around him much better. Jordan had success handed to him with the greatest coach, one of the greatest #2 players and a great supporting cast for the majority of his career. James had really good teams and not so good teams, but still managed to carry those teams to 9 finals appearances. If he had what Michael had for those years, he would've been the undisputed greatest player of all time.

What stands out in the Jordan Ã— James debate is:   - Scoring leader title: Jordan (10 times) x James (only once); - All NBA Defensive 1st Team: Jordan (9) x James (5); - Clutchness: Jordan accuracy at the final seconds of the game was about the same of the rest of the game (around 50%), while Jame's accuracy drops sharply at the clutch time.  Only weak point normally attributed to Jordan was his 3-point shots. Still, the 3-point line was introduced the year Jordan entered the league (1984) and his accuracy was around 30% (league average in the 90's), the same of Lebron playing most of his career in the 3-point era.   Moreover, there was still the hand-check rule in the 90's (at least in the paint area)

The Case Against Michael Jordan: Why He's Actually Terrible at Basketball Over the years, Michael Jordan has gone down in basketball history as one of the greatest players of all time--if not the greatest. And it's not hard to see why: his scoring and dunking abilities were truly exceptional during his prime, and his six NBA championships with the Chicago Bulls cement his place in the pantheon of basketball legends. But what if we told you that everything you think you know about Michael Jordan is wrong? That, actually, he wasn't that great of a player at all? It might sound like blasphemy to fans who've grown up admiring him. But in reality, the arguments against Jordan's greatness are numerous, and they paint a damning picture of a limited and selfish player who didn't do as much for his team as he's often given credit for. The first thing to consider is Jordan's range of skills. Yes, he could score--but beyond that, what else did he bring to the table? Not much, as it turns out. His rebounding and passing abilities were always unremarkable, and his defense wasn't anything to write home about either. Compare that to a player like LeBron James, who is a triple threat in all aspects of the game, and you'll start to see that Jordan might not be all he's cracked up to be. Another issue is Jordan's over-reliance on his individual talent. Sure, he scored a lot--but the way he did it was often at the expense of his teammates, who were left standing around while Jordan hogged the ball. Compare that to teams like the Golden State Warriors, who move the ball around constantly and prioritize passing over individual scoring, and you'll see that there are other ways to win championships that don't involve one player dominating the game. And speaking of domination: Jordan was notoriously aggressive on the court, often using intimidation and bullying tactics to get his way. You don't have to look too far to find examples of this behavior: he famously punched teammate Steve Kerr during a practice, and engaged in trash-talking on a regular basis. Should this kind of behavior really be celebrated in a sport that should prioritize fair play and sportsmanship? Finally, Jordan's impact on his teammates' performance shouldn't be overlooked. While it's true that he led the Bulls to their six championships, it's also true that his dominance may have held the rest of the team back from reaching their full potential. Former teammates like Scottie Pippen and Horace Grant have spoken out in the years since Jordan's retirement, lamenting the fact that they didn't get more opportunities to shine on the court. In contrast, other championship teams--such as the San Antonio Spurs--have placed a high priority on sharing the ball and allowing different players to take center stage throughout the game. All of this leads us to the conclusion that while Jordan may have been a great scorer, he wasn't actually a great basketball player. Fans should re-evaluate their assumptions about him and start considering what really makes a player stand out in the sport. Is it individual stats and accolades? Or is it a well-rounded set of skills and a willingness to help lift up your teammates and make them better? We'll let you be the judge.

Â TheRealist 811Â  Bro he's too slow to understand what you're saying lol

â€‹Â @vika0194Â  You seem confused.  When people talk about the GOAT, it has nothing to do with whether the person's gifts were god given or not.  That's irrelevant to the discussion. People don't say "Jordan's the GOAT of working hard" or "Jordan's the GOAT because he didn't have genetic gifts and just worked really hard to overcome his physical disabilities."  They just say "Jordan's the GOAT."    You would EXPECT the GOAT to have considerable genetic gifts.  It's part of the reason he's the goat....  Do you think Giannis isn't one of the best players in the league today because he's 6'11" with a 7'3" wingspan and gigantic hands like Jordan?  He didn't work for any of that - it's all god given.  But that isn't an argument against Giannis being a great player - he's a great player almost entirely BECAUSE of those genetic gifts.  If Giannis had gotten the genes to be 5'10", he probably wouldn't have made it to the NBA at all.  Do you think Lebron isn't a great player because he's 6'8" and has (or had) a 40+ inch vertical?  He didn't work for that - he's an athletic freak.  It's all genetic.  Most of the things that make an NBA player great are genetic gifts - the height, the vertical leap, the first step, the athleticism, the length, etc - that's literally what makes them what they are on the court.  The GOAT debate isn't about who worked hardest - it's about who was the greatest.

You know what y'all might not agree with me but I don't give a fuck. Michael Jordan accolades: 6x NBA champion 6-0 in the finals no loses. 6 finals mvp NBA record, 5 time MVP, 10x scoring champion NBA record. For those who say Jordan didn't play defense WRONG! Led the NBA in steals 3 times, Defensive player of the year, 9x NBA all defensive first team and 3rd on the all time steals list. Clutch as hell in every game that came down to the last minute always made it too. Let's not forget the 1998 NBA finals game winner over Russell. If he would have stayed in the NBA for the 93-94 season he would have had eight rings so yes I think he would have beat Hakeem and the rockets in the finals. LeBron James accolades: 3x NBA champion, 3-5 in finals more loses than wins. 3x finals MVP, 4x MVP. 1x scoring champion, led the NBA in steals 0 times never won Defensive player of the year, but he is 5x NBA all defensive first team. Yes it is true that he' s breaking records that I've lost count of and he's Hall of Fame bound no doubt. But come on the reason why he dominates the east is because the east and the NBA weak as hell in this generation all these players know how to do is run up and shoot the 3 ball. They don't know how to run plays or execute or play defense. Just saying Jordan's era of basketball was way tougher, physical and competitive. And to be honest I don't think LeBron would survive in the 80s or 90s way more tougher and physical than this shitty basketball we have today.

+Jhin the Virtuoso Player Efficiency Rating tallies up a player's stats to determine their overall productivity. MJ is #1 all time while LeBron is currently at #2 but has yet to play his twilight years which will inevitably lower his averages. Many people only tend to look at rebounds & assists to determine a player's overall skills while ignoring steals & blocks. MJ was the first out of only three players (and the only guard) to ever record 200+ steals w/ 100+ blocks in a season, and the only one to do so twice (in a row for good measure), earning him the DPOY. He reached the 200 mark for steals six times in his career. His peak was 259 steals plus 131 blocks in the same season. LeBron's is 177 steals & 93 blocks in separate seasons. Some would try to credit MJ's high PER only to his scoring, but Chris Paul is 6th all time despite only averaging 18.7 ppg while Iverson is way down at 50th place w/ 26.7 ppg.

EVERY one of these highlights have one thing in common: they are all Michael Jordan jacking up volumes of shots. That is the biggest difference between him and a player like LeBron PR Bird or Magic. Despite his vaunted "defense", Jordan only had one defensive play of note, his uncalled blineside hack on Karl Malone in Game 6 of the 1998 Finals, a game in which he went 15-35 with ONE rebound and ONE assist.  By contrast, Larry Bird's most famous play was his monumental steal versus Isaiah in 1987. LeBron has two: his epic block on Splitter and Iguodala. LeBron also had a lot of epic assists(his assist to Wade versus Philly, and rebounds, his epic put back against Boston in the 2012 Finals Game 6. Even Bird had his spectacular rebound and lefty runner in the Finals versus Houston, and his 20 rebound game in that epic Game 4 versus the Lakers in 84. I know Jordan had a notable assist to Kerr in 97 but they had to literally pry the ball out of his greedy hands to get him to pass it.

No sport is as popular as it is the best rating. Those ratings during the Jordan era through the roof. That list of ratings sums up what Michael Jordan meant to the NBA. Casual fans came to watch Michael Jordan, not the NBA. When MJ left, many of the causal fans left, and the ratings plummeted. The 1998 NBA Finals averaged an 18.7 rating because people loved watching MJ, not the NBA. The only reason the NBA Finals drew ratings of 16 and 18 from 1996 to 1998 is the presence of Michael Jordan. Basically the showtime Earvin " Magic" Johnson with the Lakers, Larry Bird with the Celtics and Michael Jordan with the Bulls drew a lot of ratings. Let's face it the ratings will never ever be like the Jordan era of the NBA Finals.

Table of NBA Finals average Nielsen ratings:  1) 1998 - Chicago Bulls vs Utah Jazz - 18.7 2) 1993 - Chicago Bulls vs Phoenix Suns - 17.9 3) 1997 - Chicago Bulls vs Utah Jazz - 16.8 4) 1996 - Chicago Bulls vs Seattle SuperSonics - 16.7 5) 1991 - Chicago Bulls vs Los Angeles Lakers - 15. 8 6) 1992 - Chicago Bulls vs Portland Trail Blazers - 14.2   The ratings are low:  2007 - San Antonio Spurs vs Cleveland Cavaliers - 6.2 2011 - Dallas Mavericks vs Miami Heat - 10.2 2012 - Miami Heat vs Oklahoma City Thunder - 10.1 2013 - Miami Heart vs San Antonio Spurs. 10.4 2015 - Golden State Warriors vs Cleveland Cavaliers - 11.6 2015 - Cleveland Cavaliers vs Golden State Warriors - 11.4  Wow!
